C\+E\+N\+S\+US E\+X\+A\+M\+P\+LE Our first extended \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a8183c2bf8d1e67778b6cf80018c89d6b}{example}} involves predicting \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} United States in 1980 using extrapolation of various fits to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} census data from 1900 through 1970. There \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} eight observations, so we begin \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a266df01acaa12f85ffe888494d501990}{M\+A\+T88}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}=8 The values of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} dependent variable, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population in millions, can be entered \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}=$<$ 75.\+995 91.\+972 105.\+711 123.\+203 ... 131.\+669 150.\+697 179.\+323 203.\+212 $>$\textquotesingle{} In order to produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} reasonably scaled \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} independent variable, time, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} transformed from \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interval\mbox{[}1900, 1970\mbox{]} to\mbox{[}-\/1.\+00, 0.\+75\mbox{]}. This can be \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6d4e164739bb3d14a7e820f8236dcb0d}{computed}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}}=sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}) The result \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} P=426.\+0950 which indicates \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} 1980 population of over 426 million. It \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} necessary for each particular installation to provide \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} subroutine which associates external text \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_a7a953fc0014129dd416edec92ec0cf5f}{files}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a0a890a7b5e140ce2ce94502357b159cf}{Fortran}} logical unit numbers.\+6. C\+E\+N\+S\+US E\+X\+A\+M\+P\+LE Our first extended \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a8183c2bf8d1e67778b6cf80018c89d6b}{example}} involves predicting \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} United States in 1980 using extrapolation of various fits to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} census data from 1900 through 1970. There \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} eight observations, so we begin \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a266df01acaa12f85ffe888494d501990}{M\+A\+T88}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}=8 The values of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} dependent variable, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population in millions, can be entered \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}=$<$ 75.\+995 91.\+972 105.\+711 123.\+203 ... 131.\+669 150.\+697 179.\+323 203.\+212 $>$\textquotesingle{} In order to produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} reasonably scaled \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} independent variable, time, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} transformed from \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interval\mbox{[}1900, 1970\mbox{]} to\mbox{[}-\/1.\+00, 0.\+75\mbox{]}. This can be \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6d4e164739bb3d14a7e820f8236dcb0d}{computed}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}}=sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}) The result \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} P=426.\+0950 which indicates \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} 1980 population of over 426 million. Clearly, using \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} seventh degree interpolating polynomial to extrapolate even \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} fairly \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2956ecc1a1b757f0d053aa446cd46890}{short}} distance beyond \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_afb358f48b1646c750fb9da6c6585be2b}{end}} of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} data interval \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} not \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} good idea. The coefficients in least squares fits \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} polynomials of lower degree can be \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6d4e164739bb3d14a7e820f8236dcb0d}{computed}} using fewer \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} columns of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} matrix. for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}=1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}=\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}(\+:, 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}})\textbackslash{}\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}}=sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}) would produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients of these fits, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac85e1322e210cd3e55055a318bee02d8}{as}} well \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac85e1322e210cd3e55055a318bee02d8}{as}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} resulting extrapolated population. \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} simply \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} average. The results obtained \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} polynomials of degree one through four all appear reasonable. The maximum deviation of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} degree four fit \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} slightly greater \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} degree three, even though \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} sum of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} squares of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} deviations \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} less. The coefficients of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} highest powers in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} fits of degree five and six turn out to be negative and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} predicted populations of less \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} 200 million \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} probably unrealistic. The hopefully absurd prediction of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interpolating polynomial concludes \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} table. We wish to emphasize that roundoff errors \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} not significant here. Also see M\+A\+C\+R\+O.(() Used to indicate precedence in arithmetic expressions in the usualway. Used to enclose arguments of functions in the usual way. Used to enclose subscripts of vectors and matrices in a manner somewhat more general than the usual way. If X and V are vectors, then X(\+V) is$<$ X(\+V(1)), X(\+V(2)),..., X(\+V(\+N))$>$. The components of V are rounded to nearest integers and used as subscripts. An error occurs if any such subscript is less than 1 or greater than the dimension of X. Some examples\+:\+X(3) is the third element of X . X($<$ 1 2 3 $>$) is the first three elements of X. So is X($<$ S\+Q\+R\+T(2), S\+Q\+R\+T(3), 4 $\ast$\+A\+T\+A\+N(1)$>$) . If X has N components, X(\+N\+:-\/1\+:1) reverses them. The same indirect subscripting is used in matrices. If V has M components and W has N components, then A(\+V, W) is the M by N matrix formed from the elements of A whose subscripts are the elements of V and W. For example... A($<$ 1, 5 $>$,\+:)=\+A($<$ 5, 1 $>$,\+:) interchanges rows 1 and 5 of A.) See(.=\+Used in assignment statements and to mean equality in W\+H\+I\+L\+E and I\+F clauses. . Decimal point. 314/100, 3.\+14 and .\+314\+E1 are all the same. Element-\/by-\/element multiplicative operations are obtained using .$\ast$,./, or .\textbackslash{} . For example, C=\+A ./\+B is the matrix with elements c(i, j)=a(i, j)/b(i, j) . Kronecker tensor products and quotients are obtained with .$\ast$.,./. and .\textbackslash{}. . See K\+R\+O\+N. Two or more points at the end of the line indicate continuation. The total line length limit is 1024 characters., Used to separate matrix subscripts and function arguments. Used at the end of F\+O\+R, W\+H\+I\+L\+E and I\+F clauses. Used to separate statements in multi-\/statement lines. In this situation, it may be replaced by a semicolon to suppress printing. ;\+Used inside brackets to end rows. Used after an expression or statement to suppress printing. See S\+E\+M\+I. \textbackslash{} Backslash or matrix left division. A\textbackslash{}\+B is roughly the same as I\+N\+V(\+A) $\ast$\+B, except it is computed in a different way. If A is an N by N matrix and B is a column vector with N components, or a matrix with several such columns, then X=\+A\textbackslash{}\+B is the solution to the equation A $\ast$\+X=\+B computed by Gaussian elimination. A warning message is printed if A is badly scaled or nearly singular. A\textbackslash{}\+E\+Y\+E produces the inverse of A . If A is an M by N matrix with M$<$ or $>$ N and B is a column vector with M components, or a matrix with several such columns, then X=\+A\textbackslash{}\+B is the solution in the least squares sense to the under-\/ or overdetermined system of equations A $\ast$\+X=\+B. The effective rank, K, of A is determined from the Q\+R decomposition with pivoting. A solution X is computed which has at most K nonzero components per column. If K$<$ N this will usually not be the same solution as P\+I\+N\+V(\+A) $\ast$\+B . A\textbackslash{}\+E\+Y\+E produces a generalized inverse of A. If A and B have the same dimensions, then A .\textbackslash{} B has elements a(i, j)\textbackslash{}b(i, j) . Also, see E\+D\+I\+T./\+Slash or matrix right division. B/\+A is roughly the same as B $\ast$\+I\+N\+V(\+A) . More precisely, B/\+A=(\+A\textquotesingle{}\textbackslash{}\+B\textquotesingle{})\textquotesingle{} . See \textbackslash{} . I\+F A and B have the same dimensions, then A ./\+B has elements a(i, j)/b(i, j) . Two or more slashes together on a line indicate a logical end of line. Any following text is ignored. \textquotesingle{} Transpose. X\textquotesingle{} is the complex conjugate transpose of X . Quote. \textquotesingle{}\+A\+N\+Y T\+E\+X\+T\textquotesingle{} is a vector whose components are the M\+A\+T88 internal codes for the characters. A quote within the text is indicated by two quotes. See D\+I\+S\+P and F\+I\+L\+E .+\+Addition. X+\+Y . X and Y must have the same dimensions. -\/ Subtraction. X -\/ Y . X and Y must have the same dimensions. $\ast$\+Matrix multiplication, X $\ast$\+Y . Any scalar(1 by 1 matrix) may multiply anything. Otherwise, the number of columns of X must equal the number of rows of Y . Element-\/by-\/element multiplication is obtained with X .$\ast$\+Y . The Kronecker tensor product is denoted by X .$\ast$. Y . Powers. X $\ast$$\ast$p is X to the p power. p must be a scalar. If X is a matrix, see F\+U\+N . \+:\+Colon. Used in subscripts, F\+O\+R iterations and possibly elsewhere. J\+:\+K is the same as$<$ J, J+1,..., K $>$ J\+:\+K is empty if J $>$ K . J\+:\+I\+:\+K is the same as$<$ J, J+\+I, J+2\+I,..., K $>$ J\+:\+I\+:\+K is empty if I $>$ 0 and J $>$ K or if I$<$ 0 and J$<$ K . The colon notation can be used to pick out selected rows, columns and elements of vectors and matrices. A(\+:) is all the elements of A, regarded as a single column. A(\+:, J) is the J-\/th column of A A(\+J\+:\+K) is A(\+J), A(\+J+1),..., A(\+K) A(\+:, J\+:\+K) is A(\+:, J), A(\+:, J+1),..., A(\+:, K) and so on. For the use of the colon in the F\+O\+R statement, See F\+O\+R . semi S\+E\+M\+I toggles the action of semicolons at the end of lines. It will make semicolons cause rather than suppress printing. A second S\+E\+M\+I restores the initial interpretation.================================================================================\+V\+A\+R\+I\+A\+B\+L\+E\+S ans Variable created automatically when expressions are not assigned to anything else. clear Erases all variables, except E\+P\+S, F\+L\+O\+P, E\+Y\+E and R\+A\+N\+D. X=$<$$>$ erases only variable X . So does C\+L\+E\+A\+R X . who Lists current variables.================================================================================\+M\+A\+C\+R\+O\+S M\+A\+C\+R\+O The macro facility involves text and inward pointing angle brackets. If S\+T\+R\+I\+N\+G is the source text for any M\+A\+T88 expression or statement, then t=\textquotesingle{}\+S\+T\+R\+I\+N\+G\textquotesingle{};encodes the text as a vector of integers and stores that vector in t. D\+I\+S\+P(t) will print the text and $>$t$<$ causes the text to be interpreted, either as a statement or as a factor in an expression. For example t=\textquotesingle{}1/(i+j-\/1)\textquotesingle{};disp(t) for i=1\+:n, for j=1\+:n, a(i, j)=$>$t$<$;generates the Hilbert matrix of order n. Another example showing indexed text, S=$<$ \textquotesingle{}x=3 \textquotesingle{} \textquotesingle{}y=4 \textquotesingle{} \textquotesingle{}z=sqrt(x $\ast$x+y $\ast$y)\textquotesingle{}$>$ for k=1\+:3, $>$\+S(k,\+:)$<$ It is necessary that the strings making up the \char`\"{}rows\char`\"{} of the \char`\"{}matrix\char`\"{} S have the same lengths.================================================================================\+B\+A\+S\+I\+C F\+U\+N\+C\+T\+I\+O\+N\+S F\+U\+N For matrix arguments X, the functions S\+I\+N, C\+O\+S, A\+T\+A\+N, S\+Q\+R\+T, L\+O\+G, E\+X\+P and X $\ast$$\ast$p are computed using eigenvalues D and eigenvectors V . If$<$ V, D $>$=\+E\+I\+G(\+X) then f(\+X)=\+V $\ast$f(\+D)/\+V . This method may give inaccurate results if V is badly conditioned. Some idea of the accuracy can be obtained by comparing X $\ast$$\ast$1 with X . For vector arguments, the function is applied to each component. atan A\+T\+A\+N(\+X) is the arctangent of X . See F\+U\+N . cos C\+O\+S(\+X) is the cosine of X . See F\+U\+N . exp E\+X\+P(\+X) is the exponential of X, e to the X . See F\+U\+N. log L\+O\+G(\+X) is the natural logarithm of X. See F\+U\+N. Complex results are produced if X is not positive, or has nonpositive eigenvalues. sin S\+I\+N(\+X) is the sine of X. See F\+U\+N. sqrt S\+Q\+R\+T(\+X) is the square root of X. See F\+U\+N. Complex results are produced if X is not positive, or has nonpositive eigenvalues.================================================================================\+H\+I\+G\+H L\+E\+V\+E\+L F\+U\+N\+C\+T\+I\+O\+N\+S abs A\+B\+S(\+X) is the absolute value, or complex modulus, of the elements of X . base B\+A\+S\+E(\+X, B) is a vector containing the base B representation of X. This is often used in conjunction with D\+I\+S\+P\+L\+A\+Y. D\+I\+S\+P\+L\+A\+Y(\+X, B) is the same as D\+I\+S\+P\+L\+A\+Y(\+B\+A\+S\+E(\+X, B)). For example, D\+I\+S\+P(4 $\ast$\+A\+T\+A\+N(1), 16) prints the hexadecimal representation of pi. chol Cholesky factorization. C\+H\+O\+L(\+X) uses only the diagonal and upper triangle of X. The lower triangular is assumed to be the(complex conjugate) transpose of the upper. If X is positive definite, then R=\+C\+H\+O\+L(\+X) produces an upper triangular R so that R\textquotesingle{} $\ast$\+R=\+X . If X is not positive definite, an error message is printed. chop Truncate arithmetic. C\+H\+O\+P(\+P) causes P places to be chopped off after each arithmetic operation in subsequent computations. This means P hexadecimal digits on some computers and P octal digits on others. C\+H\+O\+P(0) restores full precision. cond Condition number in 2-\/norm. C\+O\+N\+D(\+X) is the ratio of the largest singular value of X to the smallest. conjg C\+O\+N\+J\+G(\+X) is the complex conjugate of X . det D\+E\+T(\+X) is the determinant of the square matrix X . diag If V is a row or column vector with N components, D\+I\+A\+G(\+V, K) is a square matrix of order N+\+A\+B\+S(\+K) with the elements of V on the K-\/th diagonal. K=0 is the main diagonal, K $>$ 0 is above the main diagonal and K$<$ 0 is below the main diagonal. D\+I\+A\+G(\+V) simply puts V on the main diagonal. eg. D\+I\+A\+G(-\/\+M\+:\+M)+\+D\+I\+A\+G(\+O\+N\+E\+S(2 $\ast$\+M, 1), 1)+\+D\+I\+A\+G(\+O\+N\+E\+S(2 $\ast$\+M, 1),-\/1) produces a tridiagonal matrix of order 2 $\ast$\+M+1 . If X is a matrix, D\+I\+A\+G(\+X, K) is a column vector formed from the elements of the K-\/th diagonal of X. D\+I\+A\+G(\+X) is the main diagonal of X. D\+I\+A\+G(\+D\+I\+A\+G(\+X)) is a diagonal matrix . eig Eigenvalues and eigenvectors. E\+I\+G(\+X) is a vector containing the eigenvalues of a square matrix X.$<$ V, D $>$=\+E\+I\+G(\+X) produces a diagonal matrix D of eigenvalues and a full matrix V whose columns are the corresponding eigenvectors so that X $\ast$\+V=\+V $\ast$\+D . eye Identity matrix. E\+Y\+E(\+N) is the N by N identity matrix. E\+Y\+E(\+M, N) is an M by N matrix with 1 \textquotesingle{}s on the diagonal and zeros elsewhere. E\+Y\+E(\+A) is the same size as A. E\+Y\+E with no arguments is an identity matrix of whatever order is appropriate in the context. For example A+3 $\ast$\+E\+Y\+E adds 3 to each diagonal element of A. hess Hessenberg form. The Hessenberg form of a matrix is zero below the first subdiagonal. If the matrix is symmetric or Hermitian, the form is tridiagonal.$<$ P, H $>$=\+H\+E\+S\+S(\+A) produces a unitary matrix P and a Hessenberg matrix H so that A=\+P $\ast$\+H $\ast$\+P\textquotesingle{}. By itself, H\+E\+S\+S(\+A) returns H. hilb Inverse Hilbert matrix. H\+I\+L\+B(\+N) is the inverse of the N by N matrix with elements 1/(i+j-\/1), which is a famous example of a badly conditioned matrix. The result is exact for N less than about 15, depending upon the computer. imag I\+M\+A\+G(\+X) is the imaginary part of X . inv I\+N\+V(\+X) is the inverse of the square matrix X . A warning message is printed if X is badly scaled or nearly singular. kron K\+R\+O\+N(\+X, Y) is the Kronecker tensor product of X and Y. It is also denoted by X .$\ast$. Y . The result is a large matrix formed by taking all possible products between the elements of X and those of Y . For example, if X is 2 by 3, then X .$\ast$. Y is$<$ x(1, 1) $\ast$\+Y x(1, 2) $\ast$\+Y x(1, 3) $\ast$\+Y x(2, 1) $\ast$\+Y x(2, 2) $\ast$\+Y x(2, 3) $\ast$\+Y $>$ The five-\/point discrete Laplacian for an n-\/by-\/n grid can be generated by T=diag(ones(n-\/1, 1), 1);\+T=\+T+\+T\textquotesingle{};\+I=eye(\+T);\+A=\+T.$\ast$.\+I+\+I.$\ast$.\+T -\/ 4 $\ast$eye;\+Just in case they might be useful, M\+A\+T88 includes constructions called Kronecker tensor quotients, denoted by X ./. Y and X .\textbackslash{}. Y . They are obtained by replacing the elementwise multiplications in X .$\ast$. Y with divisions. lu Factors from Gaussian elimination.$<$ L, U $>$=\+L\+U(\+X) stores a upper triangular matrix in U and a \textquotesingle{}psychologically lower triangular matrix\textquotesingle{}, i.\+e. a product of lower triangular and permutation matrices, in L, so that X=\+L $\ast$\+U . By itself, L\+U(\+X) returns the output from C\+G\+E\+F\+A . magic Magic square. M\+A\+G\+I\+C(\+N) is an N by N matrix constructed from the integers 1 through N $\ast$$\ast$2 with equal row and column sums. norm For matrices.. N\+O\+R\+M(\+X) is the largest singular value of X . N\+O\+R\+M(\+X, 1) is the 1-\/norm of X . N\+O\+R\+M(\+X, 2) is the same as N\+O\+R\+M(\+X) . N\+O\+R\+M(\+X, \textquotesingle{}\+I\+N\+F\textquotesingle{}) is the infinity norm of X . N\+O\+R\+M(\+X, \textquotesingle{}\+F\+R\+O\textquotesingle{}) is the F-\/norm, i.\+e. S\+Q\+R\+T(\+S\+U\+M(\+D\+I\+A\+G(\+X\textquotesingle{} $\ast$\+X))) . For vectors.. N\+O\+R\+M(\+V, P)=(\+S\+U\+M(\+V(\+I) $\ast$$\ast$\+P)) $\ast$$\ast$(1/\+P) . N\+O\+R\+M(\+V)=\+N\+O\+R\+M(\+V, 2) . N\+O\+R\+M(\+V, \textquotesingle{}\+I\+N\+F\textquotesingle{})=\+M\+A\+X(\+A\+B\+S(\+V(\+I))) . ones All ones. O\+N\+E\+S(\+N) is an N by N matrix of ones. O\+N\+E\+S(\+M, N) is an M by N matrix of ones . O\+N\+E\+S(\+A) is the same size as A and all ones . orth Orthogonalization. Q=\+O\+R\+T\+H(\+X) is a matrix with orthonormal columns, i.\+e. Q\textquotesingle{} $\ast$\+Q=\+E\+Y\+E, which span the same space as the columns of X . pinv Pseudoinverse. X=\+P\+I\+N\+V(\+A) produces a matrix X of the same dimensions as A\textquotesingle{} so that A $\ast$\+X $\ast$\+A=\+A, X $\ast$\+A $\ast$\+X=\+X and A\+X and X\+A are Hermitian . The computation is based on S\+V\+D(\+A) and any singular values less than a tolerance are treated as zero. The default tolerance is N\+O\+R\+M(size(\+A), \textquotesingle{}inf\textquotesingle{}) $\ast$\+N\+O\+R\+M(\+A) $\ast$\+E\+P\+S. This tolerance may be overridden with X=\+P\+I\+N\+V(\+A, tol). See R\+A\+N\+K. poly Characteristic polynomial. If A is an N by N matrix, P\+O\+L\+Y(\+A) is a column vector with N+1 elements which are the coefficients of the characteristic polynomial, D\+E\+T(lambda $\ast$\+E\+Y\+E -\/ A) . If V is a vector, P\+O\+L\+Y(\+V) is a vector whose elements are the coefficients of the polynomial whose roots are the elements of V . For vectors, R\+O\+O\+T\+S and P\+O\+L\+Y are inverse functions of each other, up to ordering, scaling, and roundoff error. R\+O\+O\+T\+S(\+P\+O\+L\+Y(1\+:20)) generates Wilkinson \textquotesingle{}s famous example. prod P\+R\+O\+D(\+X) is the product of all the elements of X . qr Orthogonal-\/triangular decomposition.$<$ Q, R $>$=\+Q\+R(\+X) produces an upper triangular matrix R of the same dimension as X and a unitary matrix Q so that X=\+Q $\ast$\+R .$<$ Q, R, E $>$=\+Q\+R(\+X) produces a permutation matrix E, an upper triangular R with decreasing diagonal elements and a unitary Q so that X $\ast$\+E=\+Q $\ast$\+R . By itself, Q\+R(\+X) returns the output of C\+Q\+R\+D\+C. T\+R\+I\+U(\+Q\+R(\+X)) is R . rand Random numbers and matrices. R\+A\+N\+D(\+N) is an N by N matrix with random entries. R\+A\+N\+D(\+M, N) is an M by N matrix with random entries. R\+A\+N\+D(\+A) is the same size as A. R\+A\+N\+D with no arguments is a scalar whose value changes each time it is referenced. Ordinarily, random numbers are uniformly distributed in the interval(0.\+0, 1.\+0). R\+A\+N\+D(\textquotesingle{}\+N\+O\+R\+M\+A\+L\textquotesingle{}) switches to a normal distribution with mean 0.\+0 and variance 1.\+0. R\+A\+N\+D(\textquotesingle{}\+U\+N\+I\+F\+O\+R\+M\textquotesingle{}) switches back to the uniform distribution. R\+A\+N\+D(\textquotesingle{}\+S\+E\+E\+D\textquotesingle{}) returns the current value of the seed for the generator. R\+A\+N\+D(\textquotesingle{}\+S\+E\+E\+D\textquotesingle{}, n) sets the seed to n. R\+A\+N\+D(\textquotesingle{}\+S\+E\+E\+D\textquotesingle{}, 0) resets the seed to 0, its value when M\+A\+T88 is first entered. rank Rank. K=\+R\+A\+N\+K(\+X) is the number of singular values of X that are larger than N\+O\+R\+M(size(\+X), \textquotesingle{}inf\textquotesingle{}) $\ast$\+N\+O\+R\+M(\+X) $\ast$\+E\+P\+S. K=\+R\+A\+N\+K(\+X, tol) is the number of singular values of X that are larger than tol. rcond R\+C\+O\+N\+D(\+X) is an estimate for the reciprocal of the condition of X in the 1-\/norm obtained by the L\+I\+N\+P\+A\+C\+K condition estimator. If X is well conditioned, R\+C\+O\+N\+D(\+X) is near 1.\+0. If X is badly conditioned, R\+C\+O\+N\+D(\+X) is near 0.\+0.$<$ R, Z $>$=\+R\+C\+O\+N\+D(\+A) sets R to R\+C\+O\+N\+D(\+A) and also produces a vector Z so that N\+O\+R\+M(\+A $\ast$\+Z, 1)=\+R $\ast$\+N\+O\+R\+M(\+A, 1) $\ast$\+N\+O\+R\+M(\+Z, 1) So, if R\+C\+O\+N\+D(\+A) is small, then Z is an approximate null vector. rat An experimental function which attempts to remove the roundoff error from results that should be \char`\"{}simple\char`\"{} rational numbers. R\+A\+T(\+X) approximates each element of X by a continued fraction of the form a/b=d1+1/(d2+1/(d3+...+1/dk)) with k$<$=len, integer di and abs(di)$<$=max . The default values of the parameters are len=5 and max=100. R\+A\+T(len, max) changes the default values. Increasing either len or max increases the number of possible fractions.$<$ A, B $>$=\+R\+A\+T(\+X) produces integer matrices A and B so that A ./\+B=\+R\+A\+T(\+X) Some examples\+:long T=hilb(6), X=inv(\+T)$<$ A, B $>$=rat(\+X) H=\+A ./\+B, S=inv(\+H) short e d=1\+:8, e=ones(d), A=abs(d\textquotesingle{} $\ast$e -\/ e\textquotesingle{} $\ast$d) X=inv(\+A) rat(\+X) display(ans) real R\+E\+A\+L(\+X) is the real part of X. rref R\+R\+E\+F(\+A) is the reduced row echelon form of the rectangular matrix. R\+R\+E\+F(\+A, B) is the same as R\+R\+E\+F($<$ A, B $>$) . roots Find polynomial roots. R\+O\+O\+T\+S(\+C) computes the roots of the polynomial whose coefficients are the elements of the vector C . If C has N+1 components, the polynomial is C(1) $\ast$\+X $\ast$$\ast$\+N+...+\+C(\+N) $\ast$\+X+\+C(\+N+1) . See P\+O\+L\+Y. round R\+O\+U\+N\+D(\+X) rounds the elements of X to the nearest integers. schur Schur decomposition.$<$ U, T $>$=\+S\+C\+H\+U\+R(\+X) produces an upper triangular matrix T, with the eigenvalues of X on the diagonal, and a unitary matrix U so that X=\+U $\ast$\+T $\ast$\+U\textquotesingle{} and U\textquotesingle{} $\ast$\+U=eye. By itself, S\+C\+H\+U\+R(\+X) returns T. size If X is an M by N matrix, then size(\+X) is$<$ M, N $>$ . Can also be used with a multiple assignment,$<$ M, N $>$=size(\+X) . sum S\+U\+M(\+X) is the sum of all the elements of X. S\+U\+M(\+D\+I\+A\+G(\+X)) is the trace of X. svd Singular value decomposition.$<$ U, S, V $>$=\+S\+V\+D(\+X) produces a diagonal matrix S, of the same dimension as X and with nonnegative diagonal elements in decreasing order, and unitary matrices U and V so that X=\+U $\ast$\+S $\ast$\+V\textquotesingle{} . By itself, S\+V\+D(\+X) returns a vector containing the singular values.$<$ U, S, V $>$=\+S\+V\+D(\+X, 0) produces the \char`\"{}economy size\char`\"{} decomposition. If X is m by n with m $>$ n, then only the first n columns of U are computed and S is n by n . tril Lower triangle. T\+R\+I\+L(\+X) is the lower triangular part of X. T\+R\+I\+L(\+X, K) is the elements on and below the K-\/th diagonal of X. K=0 is the main diagonal, K $>$ 0 is above the main diagonal and K$<$ 0 is below the main diagonal. triu Upper triangle. T\+R\+I\+U(\+X) is the upper triangular part of X. T\+R\+I\+U(\+X, K) is the elements on and above the K-\/th diagonal of X. K=0 is the main diagonal, K $>$ 0 is above the main diagonal and K$<$ 0 is below the main diagonal. user Allows personal Fortran subroutines to be linked into M\+A\+T88. The subroutine should have the heading S\+U\+B\+R\+O\+U\+T\+I\+N\+E U\+S\+E\+R(\+A, M, N, S, T) R\+E\+A\+L or D\+O\+U\+B\+L\+E\+P\+R\+E\+C\+I\+S\+I\+O\+N A(\+M, N), S, T The M\+A\+T88 statement Y=\+U\+S\+E\+R(\+X, s, t) results in a call to the subroutine with a copy of the matrix X stored in the argument A, its column and row dimensions in M and N, and the scalar parameters s and t stored in S and T. If S and T are omitted, they are set to 0.\+0 . After the return, A is stored in Y . The dimensions M and N may be reset within the subroutine. The statement Y=\+U\+S\+E\+R(\+K) results in a call with M=1, N=1 and A(1, 1)=\+F\+L\+O\+A\+T(\+K) . After the subroutine has been written, it must be compiled and linked to the M\+A\+T88 object code within the local operating system.================================================================================\+F\+L\+O\+W C\+O\+N\+T\+R\+O\+L else Used with I\+F. end Terminates the scope of F\+O\+R, W\+H\+I\+L\+E and I\+F statements. Without E\+N\+D \textquotesingle{}s, F\+O\+R and W\+H\+I\+L\+E repeat all statements up to the end of the line. Each E\+N\+D is paired with the closest previous unpaired F\+O\+R or W\+H\+I\+L\+E and serves to terminate its scope. The line F\+O\+R I=1\+:\+N, F\+O\+R J=1\+:\+N, A(\+I, J)=1/(\+I+\+J-\/1);\+A would cause A to be printed N $\ast$$\ast$2 times, once for each new element. On the other hand, the line F\+O\+R I=1\+:\+N, F\+O\+R J=1\+:\+N, A(\+I, J)=1/(\+I+\+J-\/1);\+E\+N\+D, E\+N\+D, A will lead to only the final printing of A. Similar considerations apply to W\+H\+I\+L\+E. E\+X\+I\+T terminates execution of loops or of M\+A\+T88 itself. if Conditionally execute statements S\+I\+M\+P\+L\+E F\+O\+R\+M Enter if expression rop expression, statements where rop is=,$<$, $>$,$<$=, $>$=, o$<$$>$not equal). The statements are executed once if the indicated comparison between the real parts of the first components of the two expressions is true, otherwise the statements are skipped. E\+X\+A\+M\+P\+L\+E Enter if abs(i-\/j)=1, a(i, j)=-\/1;\+More complicated forms use E\+N\+D in the same way it is used with F\+O\+R and W\+H\+I\+L\+E and use E\+L\+S\+E as an abbreviation for E\+N\+D, if expression not rop expression E\+X\+A\+M\+P\+L\+E Enter for i=1\+:n, for j=1\+:n,... if i=j, a(i, j)=2;else if abs(i-\/j)=1, a(i, j)=-\/1;... else a(i, j)=0;\+An easier way to accomplish the same thing is a=2 $\ast$eye(n);for i=1\+:n-\/1, a(i, i+1)=-\/1;a(i+1, i)=-\/1;for Repeat statements a specific number of times. F\+O\+R variable=expr, statement,..., statement, E\+N\+D The E\+N\+D at the end of a line may be omitted. The comma before the E\+N\+D may also be omitted. The columns of the expression are stored one at a time in the variable and then the following statements, up to the E\+N\+D, are executed. The expression is often of the form X\+:\+Y, in which case its columns are simply scalars. Some examples(assume N has already been assigned a value). F\+O\+R I=1\+:\+N, F\+O\+R J=1\+:\+N, A(\+I, J)=1/(\+I+\+J-\/1);\+F\+O\+R J=2\+:\+N-\/1, A(\+J, J)=\+J;\+E\+N\+D;\+A F\+O\+R S=1.\+0\+:-\/0.\+1\+:0.\+0,... steps S with increments of -\/0.\+1 . F\+O\+R E=\+E\+Y\+E(\+N),... sets E to the unit N-\/vectors. F\+O\+R V=\+A,... has the same effect as F\+O\+R J=1\+:\+N, V=\+A(\+:, J);... except J is also set here. while Repeat statements an indefinite number of times. W\+H\+I\+L\+E expr rop expr, statement,..., statement, E\+N\+D where rop is=,$<$, $>$,$<$=, $>$=, or$<$$>$not equal). The E\+N\+D at the end of a line may be omitted. The comma before the E\+N\+D may also be omitted. The commas may be replaced by semicolons to avoid printing. The statements are repeatedly executed as long as the indicated comparison between the real parts of the first components of the two expressions is true. E\+X\+A\+M\+P\+L\+E(assume a matrix A is already defined). E=0 $\ast$\+A;\+F=\+E+eye;\+N=1;\+W\+H\+I\+L\+E N\+O\+R\+M(\+E+\+F-\/\+E, 1) $>$}}

More complicated \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a266df01acaa12f85ffe888494d501990}{M\+A\+T88}} \char`\"{}programs\char`\"{} should use \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a99c13c5700a5d8ef09125bad69607415}{E\+X\+EC}} facility. The \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a97607d1b57ca47c9c7fdb29a25fad589}{operations}} which access external \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_a7a953fc0014129dd416edec92ec0cf5f}{files}} cannot be handled in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} completely machine-\/independent manner \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} portable \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a0a890a7b5e140ce2ce94502357b159cf}{Fortran}} code. It \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} necessary for each particular installation to provide \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} subroutine which associates external text \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_a7a953fc0014129dd416edec92ec0cf5f}{files}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a0a890a7b5e140ce2ce94502357b159cf}{Fortran}} logical unit numbers.\+6. C\+E\+N\+S\+US E\+X\+A\+M\+P\+LE Our first extended \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a8183c2bf8d1e67778b6cf80018c89d6b}{example}} involves predicting \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} United States in 1980 using extrapolation of various fits to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} census data from 1900 through 1970. There \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} eight observations, so we begin \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a266df01acaa12f85ffe888494d501990}{M\+A\+T88}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} = 8 The values of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} dependent variable, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population in millions, can be entered \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}} = $<$ 75.\+995 91.\+972 105.\+711 123.\+203 ... 131.\+669 150.\+697 179.\+323 203.\+212$>$\textquotesingle{} In order to produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} reasonably scaled \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} independent variable, time, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} transformed from \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interval \mbox{[}1900,1970\mbox{]} to \mbox{[}-\/1.\+00,0.\+75\mbox{]}. This can be accomplished directly \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = -\/1.\+0\+:0.\+25\+:0.\+75 or in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} fancier, but perhaps clearer, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a50bb17654285ab47c528bd15c11e15ce}{way}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = 1900\+:10\+:1970; \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = (\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} -\/ 1940$\ast$ones(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}}))/40 Either of these \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} equivalent to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = $<$-\/1 -\/.\+75 -\/.\+50 -\/.\+25 0 .\+25 .\+50 .\+75$>$ The interpolating polynomial of degree \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}-\/1 involves an Vandermonde \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}} of order \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} elements that might be generated \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}})$\ast$$\ast$(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}-\/1); However, this \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} in an \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_ad2aaf1b57a93704deea8c793f8c0bc04}{error}} caused \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} 0$\ast$$\ast$0 when \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}} = 5 and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}} = 1 . The preferable approach \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}} = ones(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}); for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}} = 2\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}})$\ast$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}-\/1); Now \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a005a3056880026d7e5d31b3da074a132}{cond}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}) produces \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} output \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aed2591d2a093ce087083aeb946df7f2f}{A\+NS}} = 1.\+1819\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2a3e113e5b8e090e5c65a99e81e23c23}{E}}+03 which indicates that transformation of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} time variable has resulted in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} reasonably well conditioned matrix. The \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{A\textbackslash{}y}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a3a063ab18ff9fbeff794f149723fdd91}{C}} = 131.\+6690 41.\+0406 103.\+5396 262.\+4535 -\/326.\+0658 -\/662.\+0814 341.\+9022 533.\+6373 These \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interpolating polynomial \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}-\/1 \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} + \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} + ... + \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} 1 2 \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} Our transformation of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} time variable has resulted in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = 1 corresponding to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} year 1980. Consequently, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} extrapolated population \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} simply \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} sum of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients. This can be \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6d4e164739bb3d14a7e820f8236dcb0d}{computed}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}} = sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}) The result \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} P = 426.\+0950 which indicates \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} 1980 population of over 426 million. Clearly, using \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} seventh degree interpolating polynomial to extrapolate even \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} fairly \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2956ecc1a1b757f0d053aa446cd46890}{short}} distance beyond \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_afb358f48b1646c750fb9da6c6585be2b}{end}} of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} data interval \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} not \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} good idea. The coefficients in least squares fits \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} polynomials of lower degree can be \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6d4e164739bb3d14a7e820f8236dcb0d}{computed}} using fewer \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} columns of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} matrix. for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}(\+:,1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}})\textbackslash{}\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}} = sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}) would produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients of these fits, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac85e1322e210cd3e55055a318bee02d8}{as}} well \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac85e1322e210cd3e55055a318bee02d8}{as}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} resulting extrapolated population. If we do not want to \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_aeed89bed19dc9211a2f727e9985d455b}{print}} all \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients, we can simply generate \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} small table of populations predicted \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} polynomials of degrees zero through seven. We \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ade3819bf3b3e0fd29e1b0074f4990c96}{also}} compute \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} maximum deviation between \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} fitted and observed values. for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_af536e6b6e19b0639461fca9bcd715b9c}{X}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}(\+:,1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}); \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{X\textbackslash{}y}}; ... \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a1aabac6d068eef6a7bad3fdf50a05cc8}{d}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}-\/1; \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}) = sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}); \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa6c8a54562a1cca01fd261c9af754463}{e}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac96b96742620adb301595bc5046518e8}{norm}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_af536e6b6e19b0639461fca9bcd715b9c}{X}}$\ast$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}-\/\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}},\textquotesingle{}inf\textquotesingle{}); $<$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a1aabac6d068eef6a7bad3fdf50a05cc8}{d}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa6c8a54562a1cca01fd261c9af754463}{e}}$>$ The resulting output \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} 0 132.\+7227 70.\+4892 1 211.\+5101 9.\+8079 2 227.\+7744 5.\+0354 3 241.\+9574 3.\+8941 4 234.\+2814 4.\+0643 5 189.\+7310 2.\+5066 6 118.\+3025 1.\+6741 7 426.\+0950 0.\+0000 The zeroth degree fit, 132.\+7 million, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} result of fitting \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} constant to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} data and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} simply \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} average. The \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} obtained \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} polynomials of degree one through four all appear reasonable. The maximum deviation of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} degree four fit \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} slightly greater \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} degree three, even though \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} sum of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} squares of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} deviations \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} less. The coefficients of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} highest powers in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} fits of degree five and six turn out to be negative and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} predicted populations of less \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} 200 million \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} probably unrealistic. The hopefully absurd prediction of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interpolating polynomial concludes \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} table. We wish to emphasize that roundoff errors \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} not significant here. Nearly identical \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} would be obtained on other computers, or \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} other algorithms. This facility \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} useful for fairly \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2956ecc1a1b757f0d053aa446cd46890}{short}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a7ee4abe2dceee16ed21aa30d16352713}{statements}} and expressions. It \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} necessary for each particular installation to provide \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} subroutine which associates external text \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_a7a953fc0014129dd416edec92ec0cf5f}{files}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a0a890a7b5e140ce2ce94502357b159cf}{Fortran}} logical unit numbers.\+6. C\+E\+N\+S\+US E\+X\+A\+M\+P\+LE Our first extended \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a8183c2bf8d1e67778b6cf80018c89d6b}{example}} involves predicting \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} United States in 1980 using extrapolation of various fits to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} census data from 1900 through 1970. There \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} eight observations, so we begin \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a266df01acaa12f85ffe888494d501990}{M\+A\+T88}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} = 8 The values of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} dependent variable, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} population in millions, can be entered \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}} = $<$ 75.\+995 91.\+972 105.\+711 123.\+203 ... 131.\+669 150.\+697 179.\+323 203.\+212$>$\textquotesingle{} In order to produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} reasonably scaled \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} independent variable, time, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} transformed from \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interval \mbox{[}1900,1970\mbox{]} to \mbox{[}-\/1.\+00,0.\+75\mbox{]}. This can be accomplished directly \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = -\/1.\+0\+:0.\+25\+:0.\+75 or in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} fancier, but perhaps clearer, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a50bb17654285ab47c528bd15c11e15ce}{way}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = 1900\+:10\+:1970; \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = (\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} -\/ 1940$\ast$ones(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}}))/40 Either of these \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} equivalent to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = $<$-\/1 -\/.\+75 -\/.\+50 -\/.\+25 0 .\+25 .\+50 .\+75$>$ The interpolating polynomial of degree \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}-\/1 involves an Vandermonde \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}} of order \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} elements that might be generated \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}})$\ast$$\ast$(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}-\/1); However, this \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} in an \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_ad2aaf1b57a93704deea8c793f8c0bc04}{error}} caused \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} 0$\ast$$\ast$0 when \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}} = 5 and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}} = 1 . The preferable approach \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}} = ones(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}); for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}} = 2\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}})$\ast$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a339c66297df8d20f247e4e17490bb48a}{i}},\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa0b7cb0a04f82e3a2c0e877a33e0192f}{j}}-\/1); Now \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a005a3056880026d7e5d31b3da074a132}{cond}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}) produces \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} output \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aed2591d2a093ce087083aeb946df7f2f}{A\+NS}} = 1.\+1819\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2a3e113e5b8e090e5c65a99e81e23c23}{E}}+03 which indicates that transformation of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} time variable has resulted in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} reasonably well conditioned matrix. The \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{A\textbackslash{}y}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a3a063ab18ff9fbeff794f149723fdd91}{C}} = 131.\+6690 41.\+0406 103.\+5396 262.\+4535 -\/326.\+0658 -\/662.\+0814 341.\+9022 533.\+6373 These \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interpolating polynomial \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}-\/1 \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} + \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} + ... + \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} 1 2 \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} Our transformation of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} time variable has resulted in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} = 1 corresponding to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} year 1980. Consequently, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} extrapolated population \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} simply \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} sum of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients. This can be \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6d4e164739bb3d14a7e820f8236dcb0d}{computed}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}} = sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}) The result \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} P = 426.\+0950 which indicates \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} 1980 population of over 426 million. Clearly, using \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} seventh degree interpolating polynomial to extrapolate even \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} fairly \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2956ecc1a1b757f0d053aa446cd46890}{short}} distance beyond \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_afb358f48b1646c750fb9da6c6585be2b}{end}} of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} data interval \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} not \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} good idea. The coefficients in least squares fits \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} polynomials of lower degree can be \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6d4e164739bb3d14a7e820f8236dcb0d}{computed}} using fewer \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}} columns of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} matrix. for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}(\+:,1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}})\textbackslash{}\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}} = sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}) would produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients of these fits, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac85e1322e210cd3e55055a318bee02d8}{as}} well \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac85e1322e210cd3e55055a318bee02d8}{as}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} resulting extrapolated population. If we do not want to \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_aeed89bed19dc9211a2f727e9985d455b}{print}} all \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} coefficients, we can simply generate \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} small table of populations predicted \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} polynomials of degrees zero through seven. We \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ade3819bf3b3e0fd29e1b0074f4990c96}{also}} compute \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} maximum deviation between \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} fitted and observed values. for \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}} = 1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6a54b1fb39b570ed947ba9bff09da1ee}{n}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_af536e6b6e19b0639461fca9bcd715b9c}{X}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}(\+:,1\+:\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}); \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{X\textbackslash{}y}}; ... \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a1aabac6d068eef6a7bad3fdf50a05cc8}{d}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}-\/1; \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}) = sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}); \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa6c8a54562a1cca01fd261c9af754463}{e}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac96b96742620adb301595bc5046518e8}{norm}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_af536e6b6e19b0639461fca9bcd715b9c}{X}}$\ast$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}-\/\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}},\textquotesingle{}inf\textquotesingle{}); $<$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a1aabac6d068eef6a7bad3fdf50a05cc8}{d}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa6c8a54562a1cca01fd261c9af754463}{e}}$>$ The resulting output \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} 0 132.\+7227 70.\+4892 1 211.\+5101 9.\+8079 2 227.\+7744 5.\+0354 3 241.\+9574 3.\+8941 4 234.\+2814 4.\+0643 5 189.\+7310 2.\+5066 6 118.\+3025 1.\+6741 7 426.\+0950 0.\+0000 The zeroth degree fit, 132.\+7 million, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} result of fitting \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} constant to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} data and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} simply \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} average. The \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} obtained \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} polynomials of degree one through four all appear reasonable. The maximum deviation of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} degree four fit \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} slightly greater \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} degree three, even though \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} sum of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} squares of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} deviations \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} less. The coefficients of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} highest powers in \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} fits of degree five and six turn out to be negative and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} predicted populations of less \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} 200 million \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} probably unrealistic. The hopefully absurd prediction of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interpolating polynomial concludes \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} table. We wish to emphasize that roundoff errors \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} not significant here. Nearly identical \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} would be obtained on other computers, or \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} other algorithms. The \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}} simply indicate \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} difficulties associated \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} extrapolation of polynomial fits of even modest degree. \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}} stabilized fit \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} seventh degree polynomial can be obtained using \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} pseudoinverse, but \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ad6ef64fb9b12015a107b9ed4c99aac5b}{it}} requires \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} fairly delicate choice of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} tolerance. The \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a3691308f2a4c2f6983f2880d32e29c84}{s}} = svd(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}) produces \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} singular values \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a732e5473fee9bf5afa842843990cab00}{S}} = 3.\+4594 2.\+2121 1.\+0915 0.\+4879 0.\+1759 0.\+0617 0.\+0134 0.\+0029 We see that \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} last three singular values \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} less \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} 0.\+1 , consequently, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}} can be approximately \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}} of rank five \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} an \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_ad2aaf1b57a93704deea8c793f8c0bc04}{error}} less \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} 0.\+1 . The Moore-\/Penrose pseudoinverse of this rank five \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a87f6540bdacc78d66aa258ba9cb8419a}{matrix}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} obtained from \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} singular value decomposition \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a29faf1efa547eee7395013df5586bda5}{with}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} following \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a7ee4abe2dceee16ed21aa30d16352713}{statements}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = pinv(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}},0.\+1)$\ast$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}} = sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}), \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa6c8a54562a1cca01fd261c9af754463}{e}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac96b96742620adb301595bc5046518e8}{norm}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}}$\ast$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}}-\/\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}},\textquotesingle{}inf\textquotesingle{}) The output \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a3a063ab18ff9fbeff794f149723fdd91}{C}} = 134.\+7972 67.\+5055 23.\+5523 9.\+2834 3.\+0174 2.\+6503 -\/2.\+8808 3.\+2467 P = 241.\+1720 \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2a3e113e5b8e090e5c65a99e81e23c23}{E}} = 3.\+9469 The resulting seventh degree polynomial has coefficients which \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} much smaller \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4602821dafb9f6eeb17c6c1a12f02d2c}{than}} those of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} interpolating polynomial given earlier. The predicted population and \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} maximum deviation \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae2fdc33bcd49731e36913fa7258b0dc8}{are}} reasonable. Any choice of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} tolerance between \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} fifth and sixth singular values would produce \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} same \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac3184a4056593db0d92e28fe3684dc31}{results}}, but choices outside this range result in pseudoinverses of different rank and do not work \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac85e1322e210cd3e55055a318bee02d8}{as}} well. The one \mbox{\hyperlink{mold_8f90_ada23385ef8a89f31d1e7cc016012c2ff}{term}} exponential approximation \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}}) = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}} exp(pt) can be transformed into \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} linear approximation \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a40eab2bd454e9f761f2d13dffa13fb19}{by}} taking logarithms. log(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}})) = log \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a4626554aee0564362d52929f770837c4}{k}} + pt = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} + \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a246e29540014c8569d5817c74e3ab425}{t}} 1 2 The following segment makes use of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a6c8a49d5d30f0f5f9583a3417de3a97e}{fact}} that \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a8eee149f4149309724d95d04c8c53b70}{function}} of \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} vector \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a8eee149f4149309724d95d04c8c53b70}{function}} applied to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} individual components. \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_af536e6b6e19b0639461fca9bcd715b9c}{X}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a704581c21bacfe37f791e91c23af9393}{A}}(\+:,1\+:2); \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}} = X\textbackslash{}log(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}}) \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a299fe281a9836080894d14b572094b33}{p}} = exp(sum(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}})) \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_aa6c8a54562a1cca01fd261c9af754463}{e}} = \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ac96b96742620adb301595bc5046518e8}{norm}}(exp(\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_af536e6b6e19b0639461fca9bcd715b9c}{X}}$\ast$\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ae362fa87fb711c5cd8c04d7d13e173c7}{c}})-\/\mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a5b7d43e28f3684aaff673e2a784fff8e}{y}},\textquotesingle{}inf\textquotesingle{}) The resulting output \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a3a063ab18ff9fbeff794f149723fdd91}{C}} = 4.\+9083 0.\+5407 P = 232.\+5134 \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2a3e113e5b8e090e5c65a99e81e23c23}{E}} = 4.\+9141 The predicted population and maximum deviation appear satisfactory and indicate that \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} exponential model \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab631344454190053f6ff38ac01e1dc15}{is}} \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} reasonable one to consider. As \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a19cefbe49a077540b7e33d4204e4b952}{a}} curiousity, we return to \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_a2857bbd4b5d07a07f178c59b854d9c80}{the}} degree six polynomial. \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab51cd29909e4fcfd3ade3a94fbee5d45}{statement}} or \mbox{\hyperlink{test1_8txt_ab997fb21bef012bb466f3fafefe8f35d}{then}}
